Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: A Novel Form of Intraneuronal Membrane Transport
Award.AbstractNarration: Similar to the human body as a whole, cells, the building blocks of organisms, have a nonhomogeneous composition, where the different components--nucleic acids, proteins, and lipids--segregate to different parts of the cell to perform different functions. In neurons, such vital functions include the formation of stable connections, called synapses, which constitute the basis of cognition, including memory formation. To maintain proper function of the synapse, a large number of proteins and ribonucleic acids are transported from their site of synthesis in the cell body to the remote synapse. This project proposes to reinvestigate the mechanism of this transport, aiming to test the idea that many of the components needed at the synapse are transported together, rather than individually. This process would be analogous to carrying many passengers in a canoe along a river, instead of letting each of them swim in the water. State-of-the-art technologies will be used to visualize, with live imaging microscopy, the simultaneous transport of individual proteins within neurons and to purify and identify, with modern techniques of biochemistry, the components of the molecular machinery that powers this transport. These studies are expected to provide evidence for an alternate form of transport of synaptic components, thus challenging the current view of transport within neurons. Novel tools for the study of intracellular transport will be generated and made freely available to the research community. The study will be conducted with a research team that includes high school and Master's degree students, and will thus contribute to the education of future generations of scientists. The results will be largely disseminated via publications, meeting presentations, and inclusion in course lectures. The successful completion of this work will constitute a major step forward in understanding how brains develop and function at the cellular and molecular level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Outcome of the study

To maintain vital neuronal functions, a large number of membrane-bounded compartments (containing proteins and lipids that function at the synapse) are transported at distance along tubular filaments called microtubules.  Although the proteins and lipids are synthesized in the neuronal soma, in the "rough" and "smooth" endoplasmic reticulum (ER), they are transported to their destination via discrete vesicles, which recruit molecular motors to power their motility.  Molecular motors are enzymes that use the energy from chemical reactions to generate mechanical motion.  This mechanism of transport is generally accepted, and has become a dogma of neuronal biology.  We reinvestigated the mechanism of "cargo" transport in neurons, and provide evidence that some secreted and membrane proteins, instead of being carried into neurites with typical transport vesicles, are transported with ER tubules (Figure 1).  These tubules penetrate into the neuronal processes, reaching the synapse, while maintaining a connection with the ER in the soma.  Although these tubules are transported along microtubules, they require the presence of intact neurofilaments (a different type of filaments present in neurons) to extend into the neurites (Figure 2).  This is a novel and unexpected form of intracellular transport.  Since many proteins that function at the synapse could be transported by the newly discovered mechanism, our findings have important implications for the physiology of the neuron, in addition to elucidating a basic cellular function, missed by prior research.  The presence of the ER in neurites - including axons - has been previously described, mostly in relation to its function in maintaining calcium homeostasis, or as a membrane source at neurite terminals during their elongation.  However, it was not expected that the ER - an organelle involved primarily in protein and lipid synthesis - also serves as transport vehicle.

Impact of the study

Our study adds to our knowledge of the biology of the neuron by identifying an unknown aspect of neuronal function.  The discovery of a novel and unexpected form of long distance transport in neurons will change the way the field of intracellular trafficking thinks about transport in neurons, and will make an impact on future research on axonal transport, by pointing to the ER not only as biosynthetic machinery, but also as an organelle involved in long-distance transport to the synapse.

The new findings will have an impact on the pathology of the neuron as well.  Although the research carried out with this award was devoted to the study of basic cellular processes, and does not address the relevance of this work to health-related issues, we envision that the results of our research could eventually have an impact on biomedical research, and – ultimately – patient care.  As we showed, the novel transport mechanism identified and characterized by this research carries intracellular cargo that not only is essential for the function of the synapse, but also is relevant to Alzheimer's disease and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS); if perturbed, it could lead to disease.  Axonal transport is defective in many neurodegenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's disease and ALS, but the mechanisms underlying these deficiencies are mostly unknown.  The new findings could be useful in identifying such pathogenic mechanisms, raising the possibility that deficient cargo transport by the ER could cause disease.

Significance of this outcome

Our work establishes that some membrane and secretory proteins required at the synapse never exit the ER, and are transported into neurites within projections of the ER, which advance into the neurites in a manner dependent on intact neurofilaments.  Neurofilaments – one of the three main types of "cytoskeletal" filaments in neurons - were not considered as playing a role in the transport of membrane and secretory proteins.  Overall, our work is significant for discovering a novel mechanism of transport of secretory and membrane proteins that bypasses the normal transport route.

Our findings have been, and will be presented at scientific meetings, such as the Annual Meetings of the Society for Neuroscience, and the American Society for Cell Biology.  Once published, they will provide opportunities for additional research in understanding how the neuron functions.  We have already included the new findings in lectures delivered in graduate courses at Rutgers University (e.g., the Molecular Physiology of Cell Communication course, a graduate level course given by the Pharmacology, Physiology and Neuroscience Department).  The work conducted provided research exposure for Masters students, and the first research experience for high school students (from Union City High School in New Jersey).  The two students involved in this project during the summer of 2014 have both placed 1st at the North Jersey Science Fair, held at Seton Hall University.

The EAGER grant from NSF was instrumental in pursuing this basic science research with relevance to neuronal pathology, which tackled uncharted territories that may have been considered too risky for funding by other agencies.
